In 1882, the area became a watering stop and depot for the Southern Pacific Railroad.
A post office was established in 1907 under the name Lobo, after the Mexican wolves (Canis lupus baileyi) that formerly roamed the area.

event.title: the creation of Culberson County in 1911

data.event: With the creation of Culberson County in 1911, Lobo vied unsuccessfully with nearby Van Horn to become the new county's seat of government.
Another powerful earthquake struck the community in 1931.
The post office closed in 1942, but the arrival of the Texas Mica Company and two railroad houses caused a slight increase in the population.

event.title: set up a gin in Lobo, but in 1962

data.event: Anderson, Clayton and Company set up a gin in Lobo, but in 1962, the railroad stop shut down.
In 1969, Bill Christ bought the entire community and opened a new gas station as well as a general store.
The store was destroyed by fire in 1976.
In 1988, Christ placed the community on the market for $60,000.
By 1991, with no purchaser and faced with personal problems, Christ abandoned his effort to save Lobo.
